conclusion: To find the magnitude of the Ampere force received by the wire, we'll break the problem down into steps.
Segment AB has length L, current I, and magnetic field B.
The force on segment AB, F_AB, is given by F_AB = I * L * B * sin(theta).
Since the angle between the current and the magnetic field is 90 degrees, F_AB = I * L * B.
The direction of this force is perpendicular to both the current and the magnetic field (use the right-hand rule).
Segment BC has length L, current I, and magnetic field B.
The force on segment BC, F_BC, is given by F_BC = I * L * B.
The direction of this force is also determined by the right-hand rule.
Segment AB is in a magnetic field pointing into the plane of the paper, so the force direction is upward.
Segment BC is in a magnetic field pointing out of the plane of the paper, so the force direction is downward.
Since angle ABC = 120 degrees, the angle between segments AB and BC is 60 degrees with respect to each other in terms of direction of forces.
Resolve F_AB and F_BC into components: The x-component for each force is F * cos(60 degrees).
The y-component for each force is F * sin(60 degrees).
F_AB,x = I * L * B * cos(60 degrees) = I * L * B * 1/2.
F_BC,x = I * L * B * cos(60 degrees) = I * L * B * 1/2.
Net x-component: F_AB,x + F_BC,x = I * L * B.
F_AB,y = I * L * B * sin(60 degrees) = I * L * B * sqrt(3)/2.
F_BC,y = -I * L * B * sin(60 degrees) = -I * L * B * sqrt(3)/2.
Net y-component: F_AB,y + F_BC,y = 0.
The net force is purely in the x-direction: F_net = I * L * B.
